div.p: If it were not for a timely messenger, dearest Bullinger, I would not have written back at this time; for now I am less free than ever before. I am occupied all day with investigating and eradicating errors and vices.
I have no certain news from Scotland; but what I hear, Julius will report. He himself will be the bearer of letters to all of you.
My wife sends her greetings to you.
Farewell. May 23, from the journey, in Thetford.

You say you have written about the councils and sent me [two] books, which I have not yet seen: but I hope they will reach my hands. If your Christophorus comes to England, I will oblige him in whatever way I can.
Julius was with me, for whose sake I wrote to Oxford. I hear that your standard-bearer's son is with the Bedfordian.
When I come to London, I will summon him to me, and treat the Z端rcher in the Z端rcher manner. I wish all the best to all the people of Z端rich.
I wrote to you in the month of March.
Yours, John Parkhurst, Bishop of Norwich.
To Mr. Heinrich Bullinger, in Z端rich.
